Let MATH be a scheme. A subset MATH of MATH is locally constructible in MATH if and only if MATH is constructible in MATH for every affine open MATH of MATH.
Let MATH be a scheme and let MATH be a locally constructible subset. Let MATH be a generic point of an irreducible component of MATH. <CASES> CASE: If MATH, then an open neighbourhood of MATH is contained in MATH. CASE: If MATH, then an open neighbourhood of MATH is disjoint from MATH. </CASES>
Let MATH be a quasi-separated scheme. The intersection of any two quasi-compact opens of MATH is a quasi-compact open of MATH. Every quasi-compact open of MATH is retrocompact in MATH.
Let MATH be a quasi-compact and quasi-separated scheme. Then the underlying topological space of MATH is a spectral space.
Let MATH be a quasi-compact and quasi-separated scheme. Any locally constructible subset of MATH is constructible.
Let MATH be a scheme. A subset MATH of MATH is retrocompact in MATH if and only if MATH is quasi-compact for every affine open MATH of MATH.
A partition MATH of a scheme MATH with retrocompact parts is locally finite if and only if the parts are locally constructible.
Let MATH be a scheme. We say MATH is integral if it is nonempty and for every nonempty affine open MATH the ring MATH is an integral domain.

CASE: There exists an affine open covering MATH such that each MATH is reduced. CASE: For every affine open MATH the ring MATH is reduced. CASE: For every open MATH the ring MATH is reduced. </CASES>

CASE: There exists an affine open covering MATH such that MATH is not empty, MATH is irreducible for all MATH, and MATH for all MATH. CASE: The scheme MATH is nonempty and every nonempty affine open MATH is irreducible. </CASES>
A scheme MATH is integral if and only if it is reduced and irreducible.

Let MATH be a scheme. The following are equivalent: <CASES> CASE: The scheme MATH is locally Noetherian. CASE: For every affine open MATH the ring MATH is Noetherian. Any immersion MATH with MATH locally Noetherian is quasi-compact.
A locally Noetherian scheme is quasi-separated.
A (locally) Noetherian scheme has a (locally) Noetherian underlying topological space, see Topology, Definition REF.
Any locally closed subscheme of a (locally) Noetherian scheme is (locally) Noetherian.
A Noetherian scheme has a finite number of irreducible components.
Any morphism of schemes MATH with MATH Noetherian is quasi-compact.
Any nonempty locally Noetherian scheme has a closed point. Any nonempty closed subset of a locally Noetherian scheme has a closed point. Equivalently, any point of a locally Noetherian scheme specializes to a closed point.

Let MATH be a Noetherian scheme. Let MATH be an infinite subset. Then there exists an infinite subset MATH such that there are no nontrivial specializations among the points MATH.

Let MATH be a Noetherian scheme. Let MATH be an infinite dense subset. Then there exist a countable subset MATH which is dense in MATH.
A scheme MATH is said to be Jacobson if its underlying topological space is Jacobson.

A scheme is a locally ringed space with the property that every point has an open neighbourhood which is an affine scheme. A morphism of schemes is a morphism of locally ringed spaces. The category of schemes will be denoted MATH.

Let MATH be a morphism of schemes over MATH. The morphism MATH is an immersion. If MATH is separated over MATH it is a closed immersion. If MATH is quasi-separated over MATH it is quasi-compact.
Let MATH be a morphism of schemes. Let MATH be a section of MATH (in a formula MATH). Then MATH is an immersion. If MATH is separated then MATH is a closed immersion. If MATH is quasi-separated, then MATH is quasi-compact.
Permanence properties. <CASES> CASE: A composition of separated morphisms is separated. CASE: A composition of quasi-separated morphisms is quasi-separated. CASE: The base change of a separated morphism is separated. CASE: The base change of a quasi-separated morphism is quasi-separated. CASE: A (fibre) product of separated morphisms is separated. CASE: A (fibre) product of quasi-separated morphisms is quasi-separated. </CASES>
[ Separated and quasi-separated morphisms satisfy cancellation. ] Let MATH and MATH be morphisms of schemes. If MATH is separated then so is MATH. If MATH is quasi-separated then so is MATH.
Let MATH and MATH be morphisms of schemes. If MATH is quasi-compact and MATH is quasi-separated then MATH is quasi-compact.
An affine scheme is separated. A morphism from an affine scheme to another scheme is separated.
Let MATH be a morphism. Assume MATH is separated and MATH is a separated scheme. Suppose MATH and MATH are affine. Then MATH is affine (and a closed subscheme of MATH).
Let MATH be a morphism of schemes. If MATH is separated, then MATH satisfies the uniqueness part of the valuative criterion.
[Valuative criterion separatedness]  REF Let MATH be a morphism. Assume <CASES> CASE: the morphism MATH is quasi-separated, and CASE: the morphism MATH satisfies the uniqueness part of the valuative criterion. </CASES> Then MATH is separated.
A morphism of schemes is called a monomorphism if it is a monomorphism in the category of schemes, see Categories, Definition REF.
[ A scheme morphism is a monomorphism iff its diagonal is an isomorphism. ] Let MATH be a morphism of schemes. Then MATH is a monomorphism if and only if the diagonal morphism MATH is an isomorphism.
A monomorphism of schemes is separated.
A composition of monomorphisms is a monomorphism.
The base change of a monomorphism is a monomorphism.
Let MATH be a morphism of schemes. If MATH is injective on points, then MATH is separated.
Let MATH be a morphism of schemes. If <CASES> CASE: MATH is injective on points, and CASE: for any MATH the ring map MATH is surjective, </CASES> then MATH is a monomorphism.
An immersion of schemes is a monomorphism. In particular, any immersion is separated.
Let MATH be a separated morphism. Any locally closed subscheme MATH is separated over MATH.

A composition of immersions of schemes is an immersion, a composition of closed immersions of schemes is a closed immersion, and a composition of open immersions of schemes is an open immersion.

The injective (resp.\ surjective) maps defined above are exactly the monomorphisms (resp.\ epimorphisms) of MATH. A map is an isomorphism if and only if it is both injective and surjective.

Let MATH be a property of morphisms of algebraic spaces which is smooth local on the source-and-target. Let MATH be a morphism of algebraic stacks. The composition of finite type morphisms is of finite type. The same holds for locally of finite type.
A base change of a finite type morphism is finite type. The same holds for locally of finite type.
An immersion is locally of finite type.

Let MATH be a morphism of algebraic stacks. We say MATH is proper if MATH is separated, finite type, and universally closed.
A base change of a proper morphism is proper.
A composition of proper morphisms is proper.
A closed immersion of algebraic stacks is a proper morphism of algebraic stacks.

Let MATH be an algebraic stack. Let MATH be a morphism of algebraic stacks over MATH. If MATH is universally closed over MATH and MATH is surjective then MATH is universally closed over MATH. In particular, if also MATH is separated and of finite type over MATH, then MATH is proper over MATH.
Let MATH be a morphism of algebraic stacks. The scheme theoretic image of MATH is the smallest closed substack MATH through which MATH factors.

Let MATH be a morphism of algebraic stacks. Consider a MATH-commutative solid diagram MATH where MATH is a valuation ring with field of fractions MATH. Let MATH be a MATH-morphism witnessing the MATH-commutativity of the diagram. (Notation as in Categories, Sections REF and REF.) Given (REF) and MATH a dotted arrow is a triple MATH consisting of a morphism MATH and MATH-arrows MATH, MATH such that MATH, in other words such that MATH is commutative. A morphism of dotted arrows MATH is a MATH-arrow MATH such that MATH and MATH.
In the situation of Definition REF the category of dotted arrows is a groupoid. If MATH is separated, then it is a setoid.
In Definition REF assume MATH is proper (for example if MATH is separated or if MATH is separated over an algebraic space). Then the category of dotted arrows is independent (up to noncanonical equivalence) of the choice of MATH and the existence of a dotted arrow (for some and hence equivalently all MATH) is equivalent to the existence of a diagram MATH with MATH-commutative triangles (without checking the MATH-morphisms compose correctly).
Assume given a MATH-commutative diagram MATH with the right square MATH-cartesian. Choose a MATH-arrow MATH. Set MATH, MATH and let MATH be the composition of MATH with the MATH-arrow implicit in the MATH-commutativity of the right square. Then the category of dotted arrows for the left square and MATH is equivalent to the category of dotted arrows for the outer rectangle and MATH.
Assume given a MATH-commutative diagram MATH Choose a MATH-arrow MATH. Let MATH be the category of dotted arrows for the outer rectangle and MATH. Let MATH be the category of dotted arrows for the square MATH and MATH. Then MATH is equivalent to a category MATH  which has the following property: there is  a functor MATH which turns MATH into a category fibred in groupoids over MATH and whose fibre categories are categories of dotted arrows for certain squares of the form MATH and some choices of MATH.
Let MATH be a morphism of algebraic stacks. We say MATH satisfies the uniqueness part of the valuative criterion if for every diagram (REF) and MATH as in Definition REF the category of dotted arrows is either empty or a setoid with exactly one isomorphism class.
The base change of a morphism of algebraic stacks which satisfies the uniqueness part of the valuative criterion by any morphism of algebraic stacks is a morphism of algebraic stacks which satisfies the uniqueness part of the valuative criterion.
The composition of morphisms of algebraic stacks which satisfy the uniqueness part of the valuative criterion is another morphism of algebraic stacks which satisfies the uniqueness part of the valuative criterion.
Let MATH be a morphism of algebraic stacks which is representable by algebraic spaces. Then the following are equivalent <CASES> CASE: MATH satisfies the uniqueness part of the valuative criterion, CASE: for every scheme MATH and morphism MATH the morphism MATH satisfies the uniqueness part of the valuative criterion as a morphism of algebraic spaces. </CASES>
Let MATH be a morphism of algebraic stacks. We say MATH satisfies the existence part of the valuative criterion if for every diagram (REF) and MATH as in Definition REF there exists an extension MATH of fields, a valuation ring MATH dominating MATH such that the category of dotted arrows for the outer rectangle of the diagram MATH with induced MATH-arrow MATH is nonempty.
The base change of a morphism of algebraic stacks which satisfies the existence part of the valuative criterion by any morphism of algebraic stacks is a morphism of algebraic stacks which satisfies the existence part of the valuative criterion.
The composition of morphisms of algebraic stacks which satisfy the existence part of the valuative criterion is another morphism of algebraic stacks which satisfies the existence part of the valuative criterion.
Let MATH be a morphism of algebraic stacks which is representable by algebraic spaces. Then the following are equivalent <CASES> CASE: MATH satisfies the existence part of the valuative criterion, CASE: for every scheme MATH and morphism MATH the morphism MATH satisfies the existence part of the valuative criterion as a morphism of algebraic spaces. </CASES>
A closed immersion of algebraic stacks satisfies both the existence and uniqueness part of the valuative criterion.
Let MATH be a morphism of algebraic stacks. If MATH is quasi-separated and if for every diagram (REF) and choice of MATH as in Definition REF the category of dotted arrows is a setoid, then MATH is separated.

A category is called discrete if the only morphisms are the identity morphisms.

[ Categories fibred in sets are precisely presheaves. ] Let MATH be a category. The only MATH-morphisms between categories fibred in sets are identities. In other words, the MATH-category of categories fibred in sets is a category. The functor from right to left assigns to MATH the presheaf of objects MATH.
Let us call a category a setoid if it is a groupoid where every object has exactly one automorphism: the identity.

Let MATH be a scheme. A morphism MATH of algebraic spaces over MATH is said to be formally smooth if it is formally smooth as a transformation of functors as in Definition REF.
A composition of formally smooth morphisms is formally smooth.
A base change of a formally smooth morphism is formally smooth.
Let MATH be a morphism of schemes. Then MATH is formally etale if and only if MATH is formally smooth and formally unramified.
Let MATH be a scheme. Let MATH be a commutative diagram of morphisms of algebraic spaces over MATH. If the vertical arrows are etale and MATH is formally smooth, then MATH is formally smooth.

A directed set is a nonempty set MATH endowed with a preorder MATH such that given any pair MATH there exists a MATH such that MATH and MATH. A system of rings over MATH is given by a ring MATH for each MATH and a map of rings MATH whenever MATH such that the composition MATH is equal to MATH whenever MATH.
The ring MATH constructed in Exercise REF is called the colimit of the system. Notation MATH.
A module MATH over MATH is said to be of finite presentation over MATH if it  is isomorphic to the cokernel of a map of finite free modules MATH.
A topological space MATH is called quasi-compact if for any open covering MATH there is a finite subset MATH such that MATH.
A topological space MATH is said to verify the separation axiom MATH if for any pair of points MATH, MATH there is an open subset of MATH containing one but not the other. We say that MATH is Hausdorff if for any pair MATH, MATH there are disjoint open subsets MATH such that MATH and MATH.
A topological space MATH is called irreducible if MATH is not empty and if MATH with MATH closed, then either MATH or MATH. A subset MATH of a topological space is called irreducible if it is an irreducible topological space with the topology induced from MATH. This definition implies MATH is irreducible if and only if the closure MATH of MATH in MATH is irreducible.
A point MATH of an irreducible topological space MATH is called a generic point of MATH if MATH is equal to the closure of the subset MATH.
A topological space MATH is called Noetherian if any decreasing sequence MATH of closed subsets of MATH stabilizes. (It is called Artinian if any increasing sequence of closed subsets stabilizes.)
A maximal irreducible subset MATH is called an irreducible component of the space MATH. Such an irreducible component of MATH is automatically a closed subset of MATH.
A point MATH is called closed if MATH. Let MATH be points of MATH. We say that MATH is a specialization of MATH, or that MATH is a generalization of MATH if MATH.
A topological space MATH is called connected if it is nonempty and not the union of two nonempty disjoint open subsets. A connected component of MATH is a maximal connected subset. Any point of MATH is contained in a connected component of MATH and any connected component of MATH is closed in MATH. (But in general a connected component need not be open in MATH.)
Let MATH be a ring. Let MATH be an MATH-module. The length of MATH as an MATH-module is MATH In other words, the supremum of the lengths of chains of submodules.
A Noetherian ring MATH is said to be catenary if for any triple of prime ideals MATH we have MATH Here MATH means the height of MATH in the ring MATH. In a formula MATH A topological space MATH is catenary, if given MATH with MATH and MATH closed and irreducible, then there exists a maximal chain of irreducible closed subsets MATH and every such chain has the same (finite) length.

A graded module MATH over a ring MATH is an MATH-module MATH endowed with a direct sum decomposition MATH into MATH-submodules. We will say that MATH is locally finite if all of the MATH are finite MATH-modules. Suppose that MATH is a Noetherian ring and that MATH is a Euler-Poincare function on finite MATH-modules. This means that for every finitely generated MATH-module MATH we are given an integer MATH and for every short exact sequence MATH we have MATH. The Hilbert function of a locally finite graded module MATH (with respect to MATH) is the function MATH. We say that MATH has a Hilbert polynomial if there is some numerical polynomial MATH such that MATH for all sufficiently large integers MATH.
A graded MATH-algebra is a graded MATH-module MATH together with an MATH-bilinear map MATH that turns MATH into an MATH-algebra so that MATH. Finally, a graded module MATH over a graded MATH-algebra MATH is given by a graded MATH-module MATH together with a (compatible) MATH-module structure such that MATH. Now you can define homomorphisms of graded modules/rings, graded submodules, graded ideals, exact sequences of graded modules, etc, etc.
Let MATH be a graded ring. A homogeneous ideal is simply an ideal MATH which is also a graded submodule of MATH. Equivalently, it is an ideal generated by homogeneous elements. Equivalently, if MATH and MATH is the decomposition of MATH into homogeneous pieces in MATH then MATH for each MATH.
We define the homogeneous spectrum MATH of the graded ring MATH to be the set of homogeneous, prime ideals MATH of MATH such that MATH. Note that MATH is a subset of MATH and hence has a natural induced topology.

A scheme MATH is called integral if MATH is nonempty and for every nonempty affine open MATH the ring MATH is a domain.

A scheme MATH is called locally Noetherian if and only if for every point MATH there exists an affine open MATH such that MATH is Noetherian. A scheme is Noetherian if it is locally Noetherian and quasi-compact.

Let MATH be a ring. An invertible module MATH is an MATH-module MATH such that MATH is an invertible sheaf on the spectrum of MATH. We say MATH is trivial if MATH as an MATH-module.

(Definition of delta.) Suppose that MATH is a short exact sequence of abelian sheaves on any topological space MATH. The boundary map MATH is defined as follows. Take an element MATH. Choose an open covering MATH such that for each MATH there exists a section MATH lifting the restriction of MATH to MATH. Then consider the assignment MATH This is clearly a 1-coboundary in the Cech complex MATH. But we observe that (thinking of MATH as a subsheaf of MATH) the RHS always is a section of MATH over MATH. Hence we see that the assignment defines a 1-cochain in the complex MATH. The cohomology class of this 1-cochain is by definition MATH.

[Topological rings]  REF Let MATH be a ring and let MATH be an MATH-module. <CASES> CASE: We say MATH is a topological ring if MATH is endowed with a topology such that both addition and multiplication are continuous as maps MATH where MATH has the product topology. In this case we say MATH is a topological module if MATH is endowed with a topology such that addition MATH and scalar multiplication MATH are continuous. CASE: A homomorphism of topological modules is just a continuous MATH-module map. A homomorphism of topological rings is a ring homomorphism which is continuous for the given topologies. CASE: We say MATH is linearly topologized if MATH has a fundamental system of neighbourhoods consisting of submodules. We say MATH is linearly topologized if MATH has a fundamental system of neighbourhoods consisting of ideals. CASE: If MATH is linearly topologized, we say that MATH is an ideal of definition if MATH is open and if every neighbourhood of MATH contains MATH for some MATH. CASE: If MATH is linearly topologized, we say that MATH is pre-admissible if MATH has an ideal of definition. CASE: If MATH is linearly topologized, we say that MATH is admissible if it is pre-admissible and complete. CASE: If MATH is linearly topologized, we say that MATH is pre-adic if there exists an ideal of definition MATH such that MATH forms a fundamental system of neighbourhoods of MATH. CASE: If MATH is linearly topologized, we say that MATH is adic if MATH is pre-adic and complete. </CASES> Note that a (pre)adic topological ring is the same thing as a (pre)admissible topological ring which has an ideal of definition MATH such that MATH is open for all MATH.
Let MATH be a ring map. Let MATH and MATH be ideals and endow MATH with the MATH-adic topology and MATH with the MATH-adic topology. Then MATH is a homomorphism of topological rings if and only if MATH for some MATH.
[Baire category theorem]  Let MATH be a topological abelian group. Assume MATH is linearly topologized, complete, and has a countable fundamental system of neighbourhoods of MATH. If MATH, MATH are open dense subsets, then MATH is dense.
With same assumptions as Lemma REF if MATH for some closed subgroups MATH, then MATH is open for some MATH.

Then exactly one of the following holds <CASES> CASE: MATH is open, or CASE: for some open subgroup MATH the image MATH is nowhere dense in MATH. </CASES>

We have the following compatibilities between the operations above: (1) base change is functorial, (2) restriction is a combination of base change and (a special case of) flat pullback, (3) flat pullback commutes with base change, (4) flat pullback is functorial, (5) proper pushforward commutes with base change, (6) proper pushforward is functorial, and (7) proper pushforward commutes with flat pullback.
The construction in Example REF is compatible with base change, restriction, and flat pullback.

A base change of a monomorphism is a monomorphism.

Let MATH be a scheme. Let MATH be a morphism of formal algebraic spaces over MATH. We say MATH is a closed immersion if MATH is representable by algebraic spaces and a closed immersion in the sense of Bootstrap, Definition REF.
The composition of two closed immersions is a closed immersion.
A base change of a closed immersion is a closed immersion.

Let MATH be a triangulated category. Any commutative diagram MATH can be extended to a diagram MATH where all the squares are commutative, except for the lower right square which is anticommutative. Moreover, each of the rows and columns are distinguished triangles. Finally, the morphisms on the bottom row (resp.\ right column) are obtained from the morphisms of the top row (resp.\ left column) by applying MATH.

A ring MATH is said to be catenary if for any pair of prime ideals MATH, there exists an integer bounding the lengths of all finite chains of prime ideals MATH and all maximal such chains have the same length.
A ring MATH is catenary if and only if the topological space MATH is catenary (see Topology, Definition REF).
A Noetherian ring MATH is said to be universally catenary if every MATH-algebra of finite type is catenary.
Any localization of a catenary ring is catenary. Any localization of a Noetherian universally catenary ring is universally catenary.
Let MATH be a Noetherian universally catenary ring. Any MATH-algebra essentially of finite type over MATH is universally catenary.

An unramified morphism of algebraic spaces is locally of finite type.
If MATH is unramified at MATH then MATH is quasi-finite at MATH. In particular, an unramified morphism is locally quasi-finite.
An immersion of algebraic spaces is unramified.

An etale morphism of algebraic spaces is locally quasi-finite.

An etale morphism of algebraic spaces is flat.

An etale morphism of algebraic spaces is locally of finite type.
An etale morphism of algebraic spaces is unramified.

Let MATH be a scheme. Let MATH be a morphism of algebraic spaces over MATH. We say MATH is proper if MATH is separated, finite type, and universally closed.
Let MATH be a scheme. Let MATH be a morphism of algebraic spaces over MATH. The following are equivalent <CASES> CASE: MATH is proper, CASE: for every scheme MATH and every morphism MATH the projection MATH is proper, CASE: for every affine scheme MATH and every morphism MATH the projection MATH is proper, CASE: there exists a scheme MATH and a surjective etale morphism MATH such that MATH is proper, and CASE: there exists a Zariski covering MATH such that each of the morphisms MATH is proper. </CASES>
A base change of a proper morphism is proper.
A composition of proper morphisms is proper.
A closed immersion of algebraic spaces is a proper morphism of algebraic spaces.
Let MATH be a scheme. Consider a commutative diagram of algebraic spaces MATH over MATH. <CASES> CASE: If MATH is universally closed and MATH is separated, then the morphism MATH is universally closed. In particular, the image of MATH in MATH is closed. CASE: If MATH is proper and MATH is separated, then the morphism MATH is proper. </CASES>
Let MATH be a scheme. Let MATH be an algebraic space over MATH. Let MATH be a morphism of algebraic spaces over MATH. If MATH is universally closed over MATH and MATH is surjective then MATH is universally closed over MATH. In particular, if also MATH is separated and of finite type over MATH, then MATH is proper over MATH.

Let MATH be a scheme. Let MATH be a morphism of algebraic spaces over MATH. The following are equivalent: <CASES> CASE: MATH is separated, CASE: MATH is universally closed, and CASE: MATH is proper. </CASES>
Let MATH be a scheme. Let MATH be a morphism of algebraic spaces over MATH. We say MATH satisfies the uniqueness part of the valuative criterion if given any commutative solid diagram MATH where MATH is a valuation ring with field of fractions MATH, there exists at most one dotted arrow (without requiring existence). We say MATH satisfies the existence part of the valuative criterion if given any solid diagram as above there exists an extension MATH of fields, a valuation ring MATH dominating MATH and a morphism MATH such that the following diagram commutes MATH We say MATH satisfies the valuative criterion if MATH satisfies both the existence and uniqueness part.
Let MATH be a scheme. Let MATH be a morphism of algebraic spaces over MATH. Assume MATH is representable. The following are equivalent <CASES> CASE: MATH satisfies the existence part of the valuative criterion as in Definition REF, CASE: given any commutative solid diagram MATH where MATH is a valuation ring with field of fractions MATH, there exists a dotted arrow, i.e., MATH satisfies the existence part of the valuative criterion as in Schemes, Definition REF. </CASES>

Let MATH be a scheme. Let MATH be a separated morphism of algebraic spaces over MATH. The following are equivalent <CASES> CASE: MATH satisfies the existence part of the valuative criterion as in Definition REF, CASE: given any commutative solid diagram MATH where MATH is a valuation ring with field of fractions MATH, there exists a dotted arrow, i.e., MATH satisfies the existence part of the valuative criterion as in Schemes, Definition REF. </CASES>
The base change of a morphism of algebraic spaces which satisfies the existence part of (resp.\ uniqueness part of) the valuative criterion by any morphism of algebraic spaces satisfies the existence part of (resp.\ uniqueness part of) the valuative criterion.
The composition of two morphisms of algebraic spaces which satisfy the (existence part of, resp.\ uniqueness part of) the valuative criterion satisfies the (existence part of, resp.\ uniqueness part of) the valuative criterion.
Let MATH be a scheme. Let MATH be a morphism of algebraic spaces over MATH. Assume <CASES> CASE: MATH is quasi-compact, and CASE: MATH satisfies the existence part of the valuative criterion. </CASES> Then MATH is universally closed.

CASE: If MATH is quasi-compact and quasi-separated, then MATH is universally closed if and only if the existence part of the valuative criterion holds. </CASES>

Let MATH be a scheme. Let MATH be a morphism of algebraic spaces over MATH. If MATH is separated, then MATH satisfies the uniqueness part of the valuative criterion.
[Valuative criterion separatedness]  Let MATH be a scheme. Let MATH be a morphism of algebraic spaces over MATH. Assume <CASES> CASE: the morphism MATH is quasi-separated, and CASE: the morphism MATH satisfies the uniqueness part of the valuative criterion. </CASES> Then MATH is separated.
Let MATH be a scheme. Let MATH be a morphism of algebraic spaces over MATH. Assume MATH is quasi-compact and quasi-separated. Then the following are equivalent <CASES> CASE: MATH is separated and universally closed, CASE: the valuative criterion holds as in Definition REF, CASE: given any commutative solid diagram MATH where MATH is a valuation ring with field of fractions MATH, there exists a unique dotted arrow, i.e., MATH satisfies the valuative criterion as in Schemes, Definition REF. </CASES>
[Valuative criterion for properness]  Let MATH be a scheme. Let MATH be a morphism of algebraic spaces over MATH. Assume MATH is of finite type and quasi-separated. Then the following are equivalent <CASES> CASE: MATH is proper, CASE: the valuative criterion holds as in Definition REF, CASE: given any commutative solid diagram MATH where MATH is a valuation ring with field of fractions MATH, there exists a unique dotted arrow, i.e., MATH satisfies the valuative criterion as in Schemes, Definition REF. </CASES>
Let MATH be a scheme. Let MATH be a representable morphism of algebraic spaces over MATH. Then MATH is integral, resp.\ finite (in the sense of Section REF), if and only if for all affine schemes MATH and morphisms MATH the scheme MATH is affine and integral, resp.\ finite, over MATH.
Let MATH be a scheme. Let MATH be a morphism of algebraic spaces over MATH. <CASES> CASE: We say that MATH is integral if for every affine scheme MATH and morphisms MATH the algebraic space MATH is representable by an affine scheme integral over MATH. CASE: We say that MATH is finite if for every affine scheme MATH and morphisms MATH the algebraic space MATH is representable by an affine scheme finite over MATH. </CASES>
Let MATH be a scheme. Let MATH be a morphism of algebraic spaces over MATH. The following are equivalent: <CASES> CASE: MATH is representable and integral (resp.\ finite), CASE: MATH is integral (resp.\ finite), CASE: there exists a scheme MATH and a surjective etale morphism MATH such that MATH is integral (resp. finite), and CASE: there exists a Zariski covering MATH such that each of the morphisms MATH is integral (resp.\ finite). </CASES>
The composition of integral (resp.\ finite) morphisms is integral (resp.\ finite).
The base change of an integral (resp.\ finite) morphism is integral (resp.\ finite).
A finite morphism of algebraic spaces is integral. An integral morphism of algebraic spaces which is locally of finite type is finite.

A finite morphism of algebraic spaces is quasi-finite.

A closed immersion is finite (and a fortiori integral).
Let MATH be a scheme. Let MATH, MATH be finite morphisms of algebraic spaces over MATH. Then MATH is finite too.

Let MATH be a scheme. Let MATH be a representable morphism of algebraic spaces over MATH. Then MATH is finite locally free (in the sense of Section REF) if and only if MATH is affine and the sheaf MATH is a finite locally free MATH-module.

The composition of finite locally free morphisms is finite locally free.
The base change of a finite locally free morphism is finite locally free.

Let MATH be a scheme. Let MATH, MATH be algebraic spaces over MATH. <CASES> CASE: Let MATH, MATH be morphisms of algebraic spaces over MATH defined on dense open subspaces MATH, MATH of MATH. CASE: Given morphisms MATH and MATH of algebraic spaces over MATH we say that a rational map from MATH to MATH is a MATH-rational map from MATH to MATH if there exists a representative MATH of the equivalence class which is a morphism over MATH. </CASES>
Let MATH be a scheme. Let MATH be an algebraic space over MATH. A rational function on MATH is a rational map from MATH to MATH.
Let MATH be a scheme. Let MATH be an algebraic space over MATH. The ring of rational functions on MATH is the ring MATH whose elements are rational functions with addition and multiplication as just described.
Let MATH be a scheme. Let MATH be a rational map between two algebraic spaces MATH and MATH over MATH. We say MATH is defined in a point MATH if there exists a representative MATH of MATH with MATH. The domain of definition of MATH is the set of all points where MATH is defined.
Let MATH be a scheme. Let MATH and MATH be algebraic spaces over MATH. Assume MATH is reduced and MATH is separated over MATH. Let MATH be a rational map from MATH to MATH with domain of definition MATH. Then there exists a unique morphism MATH of algebraic spaces representing MATH.
Let MATH be a scheme. Let MATH and MATH be algebraic spaces over MATH. Assume MATH and MATH are irreducible. A rational map from MATH to MATH is called dominant if any representative MATH is a dominant morphism in the sense of Definition REF.
Let MATH be a scheme. Let MATH and MATH be algebraic spaces over MATH with MATH and MATH irreducible. We say MATH and MATH are birational if MATH and MATH are isomorphic in the category of irreducible algebraic spaces over MATH and dominant rational maps.
Let MATH be a scheme. Let MATH and MATH be algebraic space over MATH with MATH and MATH irreducible. Then MATH and MATH are birational if and only if there are nonempty open subspaces MATH and MATH which are isomorphic as algebraic spaces over MATH.

[ Admissible blowups are stable under composition. ] Let MATH be a quasi-compact and quasi-separated scheme. Let MATH be a quasi-compact open subscheme. Let MATH be a MATH-admissible blowup. Let MATH be a MATH-admissible blowup. Then the composition MATH is a MATH-admissible blowup.

[ Completion is neither left nor right exact in general. ] Completion is not an exact functor in general; it is not even right exact in general. This holds even when MATH is finitely generated on the category of finitely presented modules.
Let MATH be a ring and let MATH be a finitely generated ideal. The category of MATH-adically complete MATH-modules has kernels and cokernels but is not abelian in general.
Let MATH be a ring and let MATH be an ideal. The category MATH of derived complete modules is abelian and the inclusion functor MATH is exact and commutes with arbitrary limits. If MATH is finitely generated, then MATH has arbitrary direct sums and colimits, but MATH does not commute with these in general. Finally, filtered colimits are not exact in MATH in general, hence MATH is not a Grothendieck abelian category.

A field is a nonzero ring where every nonzero element is invertible. Given a field a subfield is a subring that is itself a field.
A domain or an integral domain is a nonzero ring where MATH is the only zerodivisor.
If MATH is a field, then every MATH-module is free.
Every exact sequence of modules over a field splits.
The characteristic of a field MATH is MATH if MATH, or is a prime MATH if MATH in MATH. The prime subfield of MATH is the smallest subfield of MATH which is either MATH if the characteristic is zero, or MATH if the characteristic is MATH.
If MATH is a field and MATH is a nonzero ring, then any ring homomorphism MATH is injective.

The following are equivalent <CASES> CASE: for some closed immersion MATH the object MATH of MATH is MATH-pseudo-coherent, and CASE: for all closed immersions MATH the object MATH of MATH is MATH-pseudo-coherent. </CASES>
Let MATH be a morphism of schemes which is locally of finite type. Let MATH be an object of MATH. Let MATH be an MATH-module. Fix MATH. <CASES> CASE: We say MATH is MATH-pseudo-coherent relative to MATH if there exists an affine open covering MATH and for each MATH an affine open covering MATH such that the equivalent conditions of Lemma REF are satisfied for each of the pairs MATH. CASE: We say MATH is pseudo-coherent relative to MATH if MATH is MATH-pseudo-coherent relative to MATH for all MATH. CASE: We say MATH is MATH-pseudo-coherent relative to MATH if MATH viewed as an object of MATH is MATH-pseudo-coherent relative to MATH. CASE: We say MATH is pseudo-coherent relative to MATH if MATH viewed as an object of MATH is pseudo-coherent relative to MATH. </CASES>
Let MATH be a morphism of schemes which is locally of finite type. If MATH in MATH is MATH-pseudo-coherent relative to MATH, then MATH is a quasi-coherent MATH-module for MATH. If MATH is pseudo-coherent relative to MATH, then MATH is an object of MATH.

If the equivalent conditions of Lemma REF are satisfied for the pair MATH, then the equivalent conditions of Lemma REF are satisfied for the pair MATH.

Let MATH be a finite morphism of schemes locally of finite type over a base scheme MATH. Let MATH be an object of MATH. Then MATH is MATH-pseudo-coherent relative to MATH if and only if MATH is MATH-pseudo-coherent relative to MATH.
Let MATH be a morphism of schemes which is locally of finite type. Let MATH be a distinguished triangle of MATH. Let MATH. <CASES> CASE: If MATH is MATH-pseudo-coherent relative to MATH and MATH is MATH-pseudo-coherent relative to MATH then MATH is MATH-pseudo-coherent relative to MATH. CASE: If MATH are MATH-pseudo-coherent relative to MATH, then MATH is MATH-pseudo-coherent relative to MATH. CASE: If MATH is MATH-pseudo-coherent relative to MATH and MATH is MATH-pseudo-coherent relative to MATH, then MATH is MATH-pseudo-coherent relative to MATH. </CASES> Moreover, if two out of three of MATH are pseudo-coherent relative to MATH, the so is the third.

Let MATH be a morphism of schemes. The following are equivalent <CASES> CASE: there exist an affine open covering MATH and for each MATH an affine open covering MATH such that MATH is a pseudo-coherent ring map, CASE: for every pair of affine opens MATH, MATH such that MATH the ring map MATH is pseudo-coherent, and CASE: MATH is locally of finite type and MATH is pseudo-coherent relative to MATH. </CASES>
A morphism of schemes MATH is called pseudo-coherent if the equivalent conditions of Lemma REF are satisfied. In this case we also say that MATH is pseudo-coherent over MATH.
A flat base change of a pseudo-coherent morphism is pseudo-coherent.
A composition of pseudo-coherent morphisms of schemes is pseudo-coherent.
A pseudo-coherent morphism is locally of finite presentation.
A flat morphism which is locally of finite presentation is pseudo-coherent.
Let MATH be a morphism of schemes pseudo-coherent over a base scheme MATH. Then MATH is pseudo-coherent.
Let MATH be a finite morphism of schemes. Then MATH is pseudo-coherent if and only if MATH is pseudo-coherent as an MATH-module.
Let MATH be a morphism of schemes. If MATH is locally Noetherian, then MATH is pseudo-coherent if and only if MATH is locally of finite type.
The property MATH``MATH is pseudo-coherent'' is fpqc local on the base.
Let MATH be a flat ring map of finite presentation. Let MATH be an ideal. Then MATH is pseudo-coherent if and only if MATH is pseudo-coherent as a MATH-module.
The property MATH``MATH is pseudo-coherent'' is syntomic local on the source.
The property MATH``MATH is pseudo-coherent'' is fppf local on the source.
Let MATH be a morphism of schemes which is locally of finite type. The following are equivalent <CASES> CASE: there exist an affine open covering MATH and for each MATH an affine open covering MATH such that MATH is a perfect ring map, and CASE: for every pair of affine opens MATH, MATH such that MATH the ring map MATH is perfect. </CASES>
A morphism of schemes MATH is called perfect if the equivalent conditions of Lemma REF are satisfied. In this case we also say that MATH is perfect over MATH.
A flat base change of a perfect morphism is perfect.
A composition of perfect morphisms of schemes is perfect.
Let MATH be a morphism of schemes. The following are equivalent <CASES> CASE: MATH is flat and perfect, and CASE: MATH is flat and locally of finite presentation. </CASES>
Let MATH be a morphism of schemes. Assume MATH is regular and MATH is locally of finite type. Then MATH is perfect.
A regular immersion of schemes is perfect. A Koszul-regular immersion of schemes is perfect.
Let MATH be a commutative diagram of morphisms of schemes. Assume MATH smooth and MATH perfect. Then MATH is perfect.
The property MATH``MATH is perfect'' is fpqc local on the base.
Let MATH be a pseudo-coherent morphism of schemes. The following are equivalent <CASES> CASE: MATH is perfect, CASE: MATH locally has finite tor dimension as a sheaf of MATH-modules, and CASE: for all MATH the ring MATH has finite tor dimension as an MATH-module. </CASES>
Let MATH be a perfect closed immersion of schemes. Then MATH is a perfect MATH-module, i.e., it is a perfect object of MATH.
Let MATH be a Noetherian scheme. Let MATH be a perfect proper morphism of schemes. Let MATH be perfect. Then MATH is a perfect object of MATH.
The property MATH``MATH is perfect'' is fppf local on the source.
Let MATH and MATH be immersions of schemes. Assume <CASES> CASE: MATH is locally Noetherian, CASE: MATH is a regular immersion, and CASE: MATH is perfect. </CASES> Then MATH and MATH are regular immersions.

A scheme MATH is ind-quasi-affine if every quasi-compact open of MATH is quasi-affine. Similarly, a morphism of schemes MATH is ind-quasi-affine if MATH is ind-quasi-affine for each affine open MATH in MATH.
For a morphism of schemes MATH, the following are equivalent: <CASES> CASE: MATH is ind-quasi-affine, CASE: for every affine open subscheme MATH and every quasi-compact open subscheme MATH, the induced morphism MATH is quasi-affine.  CASE: for some cover MATH of MATH by quasi-compact and quasi-separated open subschemes MATH, every MATH, and every quasi-compact open subscheme MATH, the induced morphism MATH is quasi-affine. CASE: for every quasi-compact and quasi-separated open subscheme MATH and every quasi-compact open subscheme MATH, the induced morphism MATH is quasi-affine. </CASES> In particular, the property of being an ind-quasi-affine morphism is Zariski local on the base.
The property of being an ind-quasi-affine morphism is stable under composition.
Any quasi-affine morphism is ind-quasi-affine. Any immersion is ind-quasi-affine.

The property of being ind-quasi-affine is stable under base change.

A separated locally quasi-finite morphism of schemes is ind-quasi-affine.

Hence we obtain a canonical map of MATH-modules MATH, and by adjointness of MATH and MATH a canonical MATH-module homomorphism MATH It is uniquely characterized by the property that MATH maps to MATH for any local section MATH of MATH.

Let MATH be a morphism of schemes. Let MATH be a morphism of schemes. Let MATH be the base change of MATH. Denote MATH the projection. Then the map MATH of Lemma REF is an isomorphism.
Let MATH and MATH be morphisms of schemes with the same target. Let MATH and MATH be the projection morphisms. The maps from Lemma REF MATH give an isomorphism.
Let MATH be a morphism of schemes. If MATH is locally of finite type, then MATH is a finite type MATH-module.
Let MATH be a morphism of schemes. If MATH is locally of finite presentation, then MATH is an MATH-module of finite presentation.
If MATH is an immersion, or more generally a monomorphism, then MATH is zero.
Let MATH be an immersion of schemes over MATH. There is a canonical exact sequence MATH where the first arrow is induced by MATH and the second arrow comes from Lemma REF.
Let MATH be an immersion of schemes over MATH, and assume MATH (locally) has a left inverse. Then the canonical sequence MATH of Lemma REF is (locally) split exact. In particular, if MATH is a section of the structure morphism MATH then the map MATH induced by MATH is an isomorphism.
Let MATH be a commutative diagram of schemes where MATH and MATH are immersions. Then there is a canonical exact sequence MATH where the first arrow comes from Lemma REF and the second from Lemma REF.

Let MATH be a morphism of schemes. If MATH is flat, locally of finite presentation, and all fibres MATH are smooth, then MATH is smooth.
The composition of two morphisms which are smooth is smooth.
The base change of a morphism which is smooth is smooth.
Any open immersion is smooth.
A smooth morphism is syntomic.
A smooth morphism is locally of finite presentation.
A smooth morphism is flat.
A smooth morphism is universally open.

Any open immersion is G-unramified.

REF Let MATH be a morphism of schemes. <CASES> CASE: We say MATH is quasi-projective if MATH is of finite type and there exists an MATH-relatively ample invertible MATH-module. The base change of a proper morphism is proper. The same is true for universally closed morphisms.
A closed immersion is proper, hence a fortiori universally closed.
Suppose given a commutative diagram of schemes MATH with MATH separated over MATH. <CASES> CASE: If MATH is universally closed, then the morphism MATH is universally closed. CASE: If MATH is proper over MATH, then the morphism MATH is proper. </CASES> In particular, in both cases the image of MATH in MATH is closed.
REF A universally closed morphism of schemes is quasi-compact.

[Valuative criterion for properness]  REF Let MATH be a scheme. Let MATH be a morphism of schemes over MATH. Assume MATH is of finite type and quasi-separated. Then the following are equivalent <CASES> CASE: MATH is proper, CASE: MATH satisfies the valuative criterion (Schemes, Definition REF), CASE: given any commutative solid diagram MATH where MATH is a valuation ring with field of fractions MATH, there exists a unique dotted arrow making the diagram commute. </CASES>
Let MATH and MATH be morphisms of schemes. Assume that MATH and MATH are quasi-compact and that MATH is dense in MATH. If given any commutative solid diagram MATH where MATH is a valuation ring with field of fractions MATH, there exists a unique dotted arrow making the diagram commute, then MATH is universally closed. If moreover MATH is quasi-separated, then MATH is separated.
Let MATH be a scheme. Let MATH, MATH be schemes over MATH. Let MATH and MATH, MATH points over MATH. <CASES> CASE: Let MATH be morphisms over MATH such that MATH and MATH. Let MATH be a morphism of schemes. <CASES> CASE: We say MATH is projective if MATH is isomorphic as an MATH-scheme to a closed subscheme of a projective bundle MATH for some quasi-coherent, finite type MATH-module MATH. An H-projective morphism is H-quasi-projective. An H-projective morphism is projective.

A locally projective morphism is proper.

A base change of a (locally) projective morphism is (locally) projective.
A projective morphism is quasi-projective.
